Content: :ibox:This problem has TWO parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What advice from Circe is essential for Ulysses and his men to prepare for the Sirens in Passage 1?

A.Choice: The Sirens are few in number.

B.Choice: The Sirens can predict the future.

C.Choice: The Sirens enjoy flattery and praise.

D.Choice: The Sirens never let anyone leave their island.

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 3, Circe clearly warns Ulysses about the dangers associated with encountering the Sirens, remarking that “If any one unwarily draws in too close and hears the singing of the Sirens, his wife and children will never welcome him home again ...”

Content: Fill in the bubble before the detail from the Sirens' song in Passage 1 that contradicts what Circe tells the men.

:box:	 :MC-A: “'Come here,' they sang, 'renowned Ulysses, honour to the Achaean name, and listen to our two voices. :MC-B: No one ever sailed past us without staying to hear the enchanting sweetness of our song — :MC-C: and he who listens will go on his way not only charmed, but wiser, :MC-D: for we know all the ills that the gods laid upon the Argives and Trojans before Troy, and can tell you everything that is going to happen over the whole world.' (paragraph 7)

Key.Rationale: Circe warns the men that the Sirens' intention is to keep them on the island, whereas this detail contradicts Circe's warning and describes the benefits of the Sirens' influences.

Content: Which ideas are contrasted throughout Passage 2?

A.Choice: the harshness of the sea nad the peace of the island

Key.Rationale: Throughout Passage 2, the Sirens contrast the harshness of the sea and the eternal peace of their Island, remarking that “The sea is restless and uneasy ... Come to this peaceful home of ours.”

B.Choice: the ugliness of the ship and the beauty of the island

C.Choice: the comfort of home and the toughness of the open sea

D.Choice: the excitement of the battlefield and the dullness of the sea

Content: Ancient Greece was a seagoing culture that made important explorations. Ancient Greeks also believed the sea to be a dangerous place. How is this aspect of ancient Greek culture symbolized in Passage 1?

A.Choice: The Sirens appear enchanting, but they are lethal.

Key.Rationale: The ancient Greeks were attracted to the sea and made important explorations and discoveries, but Greek culture also acknowledged that the sea was dangerous. This simultaneous allure and danger represented by the Sirens reflects this aspect of ancient Greek culture.

B.Choice: Circe enjoys the adventure of Ulysses but warns him of the Sirens.

C.Choice: The Sirens reveal important knowledge to sailors who listen to them.

D.Choice: Ulysses follows Circe's instructions, but he is tempted by the Sirens' song.

Content: In Passage 3, which element of Ulysses's encounter with the Sirens does the artist emphasize?

A.Choice: the heroism of Ulysses's actions on the ship

B.Choice: the struggle of the sailors to resist the Sirens' song

C.Choice: the menacing beauty of the Sirens' physical appearance

Key.Rationale: The artist interprets the Sirens with beautiful faces and menacing bird-like bodies. The Sirens surround the ship, and their bodies form the emphasis of the painting.

D.Choice: the dangerous nature of Ulysses's surrounding environment

Content: Select choices to show how Passage 1 and Passage 2 represent the Sirens' story differently.

Key.Rationale: Passage 1 describes the character Circe, who prepares Ulysses for his journey in meeting the Sirens.
The rhythm and rhyme of the poem in Passage 2 reveal the enticing nature of the Sirens' songs.
The repetitive imagery of “our little green isle” contrasted with the “lonely and uneasy” sea evokes a sense of rest and comfort.
Paragraphs 6 and 7 dramatize Ulysses's encounter with the Sirens as they describe how the crew needs to bind him in order to keep safe from the Sirens' allure.

Content: Select TWO ideas that show how President Nixon develops the idea of responsibility in Passage 2.

A.Choice: by highlighting areas for continued improvement

B.Choice: by outlining roles for different parts of society

Key.Rationale: President Nixon spends much of the speech thanking the American people for taking the necessary actions to weather the crisis; he also outlines plans of action for the people, the government, Congress, and industry to take in the future.

C.Choice: by minimizing the influence of outside factors

Key.Rationale: President Nixon mentions the fact that some outside forces (warmer temperatures and unexpected oil) made things easier on the country, but he deliberately minimizes these contributions in favor of the voluntary actions of the American people.

E.Choice: by using the opinions of experts

Content: Read this excerpt from Passage 2.

:box:“But the Federal Government also has a vital role to play. It must be a catalyst for industrial initiative. It must clear away the red tape that lies in the way of expanding our supplies, and it must provide the seed money for research and development.” (paragraph 18)
Why does Nixon use the word “catalyst” in describing the role of the federal government?

A.Choice: to show that the government needs to initiate change

Key.Rationale: Nixon uses the word “catalyst” to show that the government must instigate and initiate changes that will help solve the crisis.

B.Choice: to describe how the government has caused the crisis

C.Choice: to argue that the government must solve the crisis alone

D.Choice: to highlight how the government will work with the American people

Content: In Passage 1, how does President Nixon develop the idea that the energy crisis “should not result in any serious hardship for any American family”?

A.Choice: by stating the hours when gas stations will be closed

B.Choice: by outlining the plan to increase the supply of heating oil

C.Choice: by describing the progress the country has made by reducing speed limits

D.Choice: by providing examples that show the everyday effects of station closures

Key.Rationale: Nixon follows his statement by providing examples of spending more time at home and refraining from long drives. His examples provide reasons why the crisis should not result in serious hardship for families.

Content: In Passage 2, how does President Nixon's allusion to World War II reflect the purpose of his speech?

A.Choice: It highlights the historical causes of the crisis.

B.Choice: It emphasizes the importance of dealing with the crisis.

Key.Rationale: Churchill's quotation emphasizes the importance of the outcome of World War II. Nixon quotes Churchill to highlight the importance of the energy crisis.

C.Choice: It reassures people that the crisis is coming to an end.

D.Choice: It shows that problems are best solved through strong leadership.

Content: :ibox:This problem has TWO parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What argument does President Nixon make in Passage 1?

A.Choice: People must make sacrifices to help the government deal with the crisis.

Key.Rationale: Much of Nixon's speech is about new laws that will go into effect, but the key point he makes is that Americans will need to willingly make compromises to meet the crisis successfully.

B.Choice: Following the president's plan will bring an end to the energy crisis.

C.Choice: Driving on weekends was a factor that caused the energy crisis.

D.Choice: America will be better prepared for another crisis in the future.

Content: Which sentence from Passage 2 supports the answer in Part A?

A.Choice: “For the past 7 weeks, we have observed 'gasless Sundays' across the country.” (paragraph 6)

B.Choice: “These are just some of the steps we have taken to meet the problem head-on, and you can expect more in the future.” (paragraph 14)

C.Choice: “Nothing which the Federal Government might do could be successful, however, without the full cooperation of the American people.” (paragraph 15)

Key.Rationale: President Nixon reiterates that the success of his various plans in Passage 1 relies on voluntary cooperation as much as new laws and regulations.

D.Choice: “Late last year, I announced the beginning of Project Independence, a full-scale effort to provide the capacity to meet American energy needs with American energy resources by 1980.” (paragraph 17)

Content: Which TWO arguments in Passage 1 are supported by evidence?

A.Choice: Reducing the temperature in homes and offices will keep people warm through the winter.

B.Choice: The American people's cooperation will be key to the overall success of the plan.

C.Choice: President Nixon is taking the necessary steps to move his plans forward.

Key.Rationale: President Nixon mentions several specific actions that he is taking, such as legislation being enacted by Congress, that will have an effect on the crisis.

D.Choice: Operating cars at certain speeds will save gasoline.

E.Choice: Closing gas stations will result in less driving.

Key.Rationale: President Nixon presents a number of plans in this passage, but the estimated gasoline savings represent one of the few hard numbers used to support his arguments.

Content: Select choices before THREE sentences from Passage 2 that provide evidence that government action lessens the burdens of the crisis for Americans.

:box:	 :MC-A: A fuel allocation program has been set up so that no area of the Nation is being subjected to undue hardship. :MC-B: We have begun the process of converting oil-burning utilities to the use of coal wherever possible, freeing some 200,000 barrels of oil a day for use in other areas.
	 :MC-C: At my request, laws governing energy conservation, such as year-round daylight savings time, have been enacted by the Congress and are now in effect. :MC-D: Teams of Federal inspectors have been sent to investigate fuel prices at gasoline stations and truck stops. :MC-E: Where price gouging is discovered, it is being stopped.
	 :MC-F: Within the Government, where we have a special obligation to set an example, I first directed that energy consumption be cut by at least 7 percent. :MC-G: That goal has now been met, and it has been exceeded. :MC-H: Consumption of energy by the Federal Government has been cut by more than 20 percent under anticipated demands. (paragraphs 11 - 13)

Key.Rationale: This choice describes how resources are being allocated by the government to lessen the burden of the crisis for Americans.
This choice describes how the government is protecting its citizens from price gouging, therefore lessening the crisis for Americans.
This choice describes a specific method the government is using to protect its citizens, therefore lessening the crisis for Americans.

Content: Both of these speeches by President Nixon discuss the energy crisis. How do the two passages differ in their message?

A.Choice: Passage 1 warns that the crisis will get worse, while Passage 2 insists that the crisis will be resolved.

B.Choice: Passage 1 focuses on immediate actions, while Passage 2 deals plans for the future.

Key.Rationale: The largest thematic difference between the passages is that Passage 1 deals with steps that ordinary Americans can take to mitigate the dangers of the current energy crisis, while Passage 2 sets its sights on preventing future energy crises.

C.Choice: Passage 1 supports government action, while Passage 2 suggests action by the people.

D.Choice: Passage 1 states that the crisis is exaggerated, while Passage 2 takes the crisis seriously.

Content: Choose the correct word or phrase to replace the underlined part of the following sentence.

:box:To my mother, good food meant fresh ingredients; to my father, good food meant that there was a lot of it; a͟n͟d͟ ͟m͟y͟ ͟g͟r͟a͟n͟d͟m͟o͟t͟h͟e͟r͟ ͟t͟h͟o͟u͟g͟h͟t good food meant that you had taken the time to do all of the little details yourself.

Key.Rationale: This choice shows the correct use of parallelism and sentence structure after a semicolon.

Content: Choose the correct word or phrase to replace the underlined part of the following sentence.
:box:My grandmother was of French a͟n͟c͟e͟s͟t͟r͟y͟ ͟t͟h͟e͟r͟e͟f͟o͟r͟e͟, her bread reflected that heritage.

Key.Rationale: This choice shows the correct use of a semicolon with conjunctive adverbs.

Content: Choose the correct word or phrase to replace the underlined part of the following sentence.
:box:In the evening, my grandmother would make a sticky, shaggy mess out of the most basic mix of i͟n͟g͟r͟e͟d͟i͟e͟n͟t͟s͟: water, salt, flour, and starter.

Key.Rationale: This choice shows the correct use of a colon to precede a list of items.

Content: :box:There was nothing g͟l͟a͟m͟o͟r͟u͟s about the work, but the transformation of those simple ingredients seemed like magic.

Key.Rationale: This choice shows the correct spelling of the word “glamorous.”

Content: Choose the correct punctuation to replace the underlined part of the first paragraph.

Key.Rationale: A colon is needed to introduce the quotation.

Content: Choose the correct phrase to be used in the sentence to replace the underlined part of the second paragraph.

A.Choice: and construct the tartans worn in their towns

B.Choice: and constructed the tartans worn in their towns

Key.Rationale: This phrase creates the correct parallel structure.

C.Choice: and they would construct the tartans worn in their towns

Content: Choose the correct punctuation to replace the underlined part of the third paragraph.

A.Choice: pride: it didn't become legal again until 1782

B.Choice: pride; it didn't become legal again until 1782

Key.Rationale: This is the correct punctuation to use.

C.Choice: pride it didn't become legal again until 1782
